channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Hawking Israel boycott causes stir
item.description: A decision by world-renowned physicist Stephen Hawking not to attend a conference in Israel in support of an academic boycott of the country has sparked controversy in Israel and a vitriolic debate online.

item.title: Brazilian woman shot with harpoon
item.description: A Brazilian woman escaped death by less than an inch after her husband accidentally shot her with a harpoon.

item.title: White House blasted on Benghazi attack
item.description: The Obama administration's handling of the aftermath of the Benghazi terror attack has long sparked outrage from Republicans on Capitol Hill and fueled conspiracy theories on talk shows and across the blogosphere.

item.title: Inside Cleveland's 'haunted house'
item.description: In retrospect, there were plenty of signs something was wrong: A naked woman seen in the yard, child peering from an attic, muffled screams.

item.title: South: Korean reunification still possible
item.description: The future of the Korean peninsula relies on U.S. involvement in the peace process, South Korean President Park Geun-hye told a joint meeting of Congress Wednesday.

item.title: Why Clinton is real Benghazi target
item.description: David Rothkopf says investigation into Benghazi is worthy, but Rep. Issa's committee hearings were for something different: To damage theone most likely to be next Democratic presidential candidate.

item.title: Sharif: Veteran of Pakistan tumult
item.description: Nawaz Sharif, a stout 63-year-old, has already had a long and rocky career that includes two stints as prime minister during the 1990s

item.title: Why Gitmo force feeding is torture
item.description: Vince Warren says President Obama chooses to force feed hunger strikers at Gitmo, a form of torture, and should be shutting the prison down instead.

item.title: Never give up hope to find missing
item.description: Philip Lerman learned from working at "America's Most Wanted" on missing children cases that the hardest thing to do is the only thing to do: Never give up

item.title: Prosecutor: Kidnap suspect operated 'torture chamber'
item.description: Accused of holding women for almost a decade, Ariel Castro may also face charges of murder in the termination of his captives' pregnancies, a prosecutor says.

item.title: Castro's daughter: 'He's dead to me'
item.description: A daughter of an Ohio man accused of holding women against their will for the better part of a decade said Thursday that pieces of her father's life she didn't understand are falling into place.

item.title: Her interview
item.description: Ariel Castro's daughter Angie Gregg says she never wants to see him again.

item.title: Neighbor played a key role in escape
item.description: The three women and a child who were freed Monday after years of imprisonment inside a Cleveland house may have remained trapped had it not been for the efforts of a man who was visiting two women on the porch of a house across the street.

item.title: Unanswered questions in captive case
item.description: A flood of details has emerged in the past 24 hours about the case of Ariel Castro and the three women police say he held for close to a decade inside his modest Cleveland home.

item.title: Timeline
item.description: Lorain Avenue is where the nightmare began for three women held captive in a Cleveland home for roughly a decade.

item.title: Olympian killed as catamaran capsizes
item.description: Friends and fellow sailors mourned double Olympic medalist Andrew "Bart" Simpson after the shocking news that he had died in San Francisco Bay while training for the America's Cup.

item.title: Dhaka collapse toll rises above 1,000
item.description: More than two weeks after a building in Bangladesh housing factories full of garment workers caved in, the death toll from the South Asian nation's deadliest industrial disaster has surpassed 1,000, authorities said Friday.

item.title: NASA: Space Station is leaking ammonia
item.description: The International Space Station is once again leaking ammonia from a cooling system, NASA said Thursday in a news release.

item.title: N. Korea lists American's 'hostile acts'
item.description: North Korea for the first time publicly specified the "hostile acts" that landed Kenneth Bae a 15-year sentence at a labor camp.

item.title: Korean aide axed for 'unsavory incident'
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea has dismissed her press spokesman after concluding that he was involved in an "unsavory incident" during a state visit to the United States, her office said.

item.title: Deadly virus diagnosed in France
item.description: A newly discovered potentially deadly virus related to the one that causes the common cold has infected another person, this time in France.

item.title: Tunisian held in U.S. on terror charges
item.description: A Tunisian, who authorities believe radicalized one of the suspects held in Canada on charges of plotting to blow up a passenger train, has been arrested in New York on unrelated counts, according to authorities who said he wanted to commit acts of terror in the United States.

item.title: Ex-dictator rejects genocide charges
item.description: Former Guatemalan dictator Efrain Rios Montt waited until closing arguments to speak in his own defense in his genocide trial in Guatemala City on Thursday.

item.title: U.S.: Remove 3-D gun instructions
item.description: The U.S. State Department said Thursday it had heard enough from Defense Distributed, the non-profit group at the center of a 3-D gun printing controversy.

item.title: Scores of police killed in Nigeria
item.description: Scores of police officers have been killed during attacks in Nasarawa State in central Nigeria, the Nigerian Police High Command said Thursday.

item.title: Boston suspect entombed in secret
item.description: The difficult question of where Tamerlan Tsarnaev should be buried appears to have been settled.

item.title: Arias: 'I'd rather get death penalty'
item.description: A day after a jury found her guilty of first-degree murder in the slaying of her ex-boyfriend, Jodi Arias will return to court Thursday to begin a phase that will move her closer to learning whether she will live or die.

item.title: 2 Carnival Cruise passengers missing
item.description: Authorities launched a search Thursday after two passengers went missing overnight off Australia's eastern coast.

item.title: Guatemala genocide charges rejected
item.description: Former Guatemalan dictator Efrain Rios Montt waited until closing arguments to speak in his own defense in his genocide trial in Guatemala City on Thursday.

item.title: Moyes signs six-year Man United deal
item.description: David Moyes has been appointed as the new manager of Manchester United after agreeing a six-year deal.

item.title: 'American Idol' original Jackson leaving
item.description: Randy Jackson, the last original "American Idol" judge, announced Thursday that he's voting himself off the hit singing competition program after the current season ends.

item.title: Man flees police, is grabbed by gator
item.description: A Florida man fleeing a traffic stop almost got away, police say. Until he met up with an alligator.

item.title: Former Pakistani PM's son kidnapped
item.description: A son of a former Pakistani prime minister was kidnapped Thursday in a deadly raid two days before the son is to stand for provincial assembly elections, one of his brothers told CNN.

item.title: Who is frontrunner Nawaz Sharif?
item.description: The strongest contender to become the next Pakistani prime minister is hardly a newcomer to the country's political stage.

item.title: Voters to go to polls amid tension
item.description: When Pakistanis go to the polls on Saturday they will be electing key players battling to govern one of the world's most complicated countries.

item.title: Pakistani hopes
item.description: Pakistanis air their election views and why they are voting to CNN's Open Mic in Islamabad.

item.title: See massive tornado sweep up land
item.description: A massive tornado touches down near Modena, Italy.

item.title: Ramsey describes Berry rescue
item.description: Charles Ramsey tells Anderson Cooper how he found Amanda Berry, a woman who vanished years ago, in his neighbor's house.

item.title: Knox feels bad for younger self
item.description: Amanda Knox tells CNN's Chris Cuomo about her regrets when dealing with investigators after Meredith Kercher's death.

item.title: China vets remember Korean War
item.description: CNN's Ivan Watson talks to Chinese veterans from the Korean War and finds they have a surprising perspective.

item.title: DeJesus' brother: 'You're finally home'
item.description: Georgina DeJesus reunites with her family in Cleveland after nine years of heartbreak.

item.title: Police address Berry's 911 call
item.description: Det. Ciaccia says Cleveland police will look at how a dispatcher handled Amanda Berry's call, but the response was swift.

item.title: Hawking's Israel boycott backlash
item.description: Scientist Stephen Hawking receives backlash online after he boycotts an Israeli academic conference.

item.title: Slavery is not dead in France
item.description: As France commemorates the abolishment of slavery in the past, it remains haunted by slavery in the present.

item.title: Meet the blind boxer making history
item.description: CNN's Ayesha Durgahee reports on a blind boxer in Uganda and his attempt to make history.

item.title: How did woman survive this?
item.description: A Brazilian woman escaped death by less than an inch after her husband accidentally shot her in the mouth this week with a harpoon, authorities said.

item.title: Witness: Jackson paranoid in last days
item.description: Michael Jackson appeared paranoid, repeating himself and shivering from chills in his final days, his longtime makeup artist testified Thursday.

item.title: The most popular baby names are...
item.description: So, maybe some of you new parents have seen this show, "Game of Thrones?"

item.title: Athlete, 102: Running brought my life back
item.description: At an age when most pensioners are winding down their lives, Fauja Singh began a new one. In his late 80s, and feeling "more dead than alive" following the loss of his wife and one of his sons, he took up marathon running. Now 102, he has become an unlikely celebrity despite a birth defect that prevented him being able to walk until the age of five.

item.title: Will any other European royals step down?
item.description: As royal guests watched the Dutch monarchy change hands, some may have been looking to the day when they get the top job back home.

item.title: Would you buy a Huawei smartphone?
item.description: Who is the world's third biggest smartphone maker? BlackBerry? HTC? Nope. It's China's Huawei.

item.title: Does architecture exclude women?
item.description: From a wing of the National Gallery in Trafalgar Square, London, to the provincial capitol building in Toulouse, France to a spa resort in Japan, Denise Scott Brown's architecture has changed landscapes across the globe.

item.title: 'Slavery' accusations dog World Cup hosts
item.description: Qatar's image is being tarred by claims players and construction workers are being abused.

item.title: 7/7 survivor: How Boston can heal
item.description: Gill Hicks lost both legs in the 2005 London bombings that killed 52 people. But she says Boston victims can find new hope in the "brilliance of humanity."

item.title: Studying the history of cannibalism
item.description: CNN's Becky Anderson talks to science journalist Sarah Everts about instances of cannibalism in history.

item.title: 'Mr Incredible' faces new task
item.description: The man behind India's tourism ads wants to bring the country up to speed with a new multi-billion dollar project.

item.title: Math whiz masters translation
item.description: CNN's Nick Glass meets a German mathematician who wants to revolutionize the world of automated translation.

item.title: Senate staffers scream for Harry
item.description: CNN's Max Foster details Prince Harry's visit to the U.S. and his first stop, Capitol Hill.

item.title: Time to buy Hong Kong property?
item.description: The volume of Hong Kong property sales fell 60% compared with last year -- a sign that one of the world's most expensive markets is cooling.

item.title: WTO and emerging market's muscle
item.description: It did not happen when the top job opened up at the International Monetary Fund: Christine Lagarde of France won out over candidates such as Mexico's Central Bank Governor Agustin Carstens, who put up a good fight.

item.title: 'Unfilmable' tales? Not for Hollywood
item.description: On paper, the 1974 version of "The Great Gatsby" had everything.

item.title: What happened to the ringtone?
item.description: In the early- to mid-2000s, the ability to play a customized sound for incoming calls -- usually a blaring few seconds of a favorite song called a "mastertone" -- was a fun novelty for people buying their first cellphones. But there has been a sharp decline in ringtone sales over the last half-decade.

item.title: 'Super chair' changes lives
item.description: Sometimes, implementing wide-reaching social change takes surprisingly few materials. With just a handful of bike gears, MIT professor Amos Winter is hoping to change the developing word forever.

item.title: Squatting in Brazil's faded luxury
item.description: CNN's Shasta Darlington talks to families squatting in faded luxury.

item.title: Meet the real-life 'Robocop'
item.description: Take a pair hi-fi speakers, an old radio, a couple of DVD players and countless other household appliances, apply some ingenuity and what do you get?

item.title: Inside the hunt for Somali pirates
item.description: CNN got an exclusive look as African Union security forces hunt for pirates in the waters off Somalia.

item.title: Will 'flying' boat smash record?
item.description: 20 years of passion and a few million euros later, a French sailor has created the Hydroptere -- one of the fastest sailboats in the world.

item.title: African midwife, Nobel Peace Prize?
item.description: Ugandan midwife Esther Madudu has been chosen by AMREF to front its "Stand Up For African Mothers" campaign, an initiative aiming to train an additional 15,000 midwifes by 2015.

item.title: Meet Saudi's first female lawyer
item.description: As Arwa Al-Hujaili begins her legal career, she has not only her own expectations to live up to, but those of a generation: she has just become Saudi Arabia's first female lawyer.

item.title: How to throw party worthy of Gatsby
item.description: Russell Bailyn and Jay Gatsby have several things in common: They are both wealthy, live in Long Island, and know how to throw a great 1920s party.

item.title: 'Lost continent' found near Brazil?
item.description: A team of scientists say they may have discovered part of a "lost continent" deep in the Atlantic off of Brazil.

item.title: Why Syria now looks worse
item.description: What began as a protest movement in Syria has become an uprising that spread into a war, a vicious whirlpool that threatens to embroil its neighbors and pose complex challenges to the Obama administration.

item.title: Timelapse guys' cabin ransacked
item.description: The vacation cabin of five guys who took same photo for 30 years was burglarized.

item.title: Malala's voice stronger than ever
item.description: The school year started with a shooting. Now, Malala eyes a summer of speaking at the U.N. and telling her story in a new book.

item.title: Mask gives bionic powers
item.description: Fans of "Iron Man," take note: Students have created masks to give superhuman sight and hearing.

item.title: Shadow over activist's greatest moment
item.description: Cecilia Flores-Oebanda has fought for 20 years against human traffickers. Now she's fighting for her reputation.

item.title: Child advocate calls on Pacquiao
item.description: "The Fighters" documents an advocate who tries to convince Manny Pacquiao to join her fight against modern day slavery.

item.title: Face transplant patients: Where are they now?
item.description: Since 2008, several landmark face transplants have given people with severely deformed faces new lives. Read their stories.

item.title: Face recipient's goal: A kiss
item.description: After Carmen Tarleton's estranged husband doused her with industrial-strength lye, doctors saved her life with a medically induced coma and more than 50 surgeries.

item.title: Egypt's nostalgia for days of Mubarak
item.description: As post-Arab Spring Egypt grapples with violence, instability and a troubled economy, more Egyptians say they're yearning for the days when Hosni Mubarak ruled -- and his supporters are saying "we told you so!"

item.title: NASA: Space Station has sprung a leak
item.description: Astronauts aboard the ISS are preparing to repair an ammonia leak in the station's external cooling system.

item.title: Olympian killed
item.description: Friends and fellow sailors mourned double Olympic medalist Andrew "Bart" Simpson after the shocking news that he had died in San Francisco Bay while training for the America's Cup.

item.title: Kidnap suspect
item.description: Ohio suspect Ariel Castro maintained his home as a prison for three young women, holding them in seclusion and sexually assaulting them, a prosecutor tells a judge.

item.title: Space Station leak
item.description: Crew members aboard the International Space Station are awaiting word on how to deal with leaking ammonia from an outside cooling system, NASA said Thursday in a news release.

item.title: Moyes at Man United
item.description: David Moyes has been appointed as the new manager of Manchester United after agreeing a six-year deal.

item.title: Harpoon horror
item.description: A Brazilian woman escaped death by less than an inch after her husband accidentally shot her in the mouth this week with a harpoon, authorities said.

item.title: The Fighters
item.description: Cecilia Flores-Oebanda has spent her life fighting -- as a child for some education, as a teen rebel against a dictator, and for more than 20 years against human traffickers.

item.title: Why China involved in Africa's health
item.description: There is an old African proverb: "If you want to walk fast, walk alone. But if you want to walk far, walk together."

item.title: Cold case grips Chinese netizens
item.description: A cold case involving the poisoning of a college sophomore in Beijing almost two decades ago has captured the imagination of Chinese communities around the world, landing a petition on the White House website and igniting an emotional debate on the pursuit of justice in China.

item.title: China reduces banking lifeline to N. Korea
item.description: The Bank of China has stopped doing business with a large North Korean bank, falling into line with a US-led sanctions push to restrict funding for Pyongyang's nuclear programme.

item.title: Poultry trade may spread bird flu
item.description: Poultry workers moving to and from wet markets and farms may be responsible for the spread of the deadly H7N9 virus in China, says a virologist who's working with the World Health Organisation to investigate the outbreak.

item.title: Police seize tons of bogus meat
item.description: Police in China have spent three months seizing bogus meat, some of it fake beef or mutton made out of fox, mink and rat.

item.title: 'Baby' Ye makes Tour history
item.description: China's young golfers mixed the rough with the smooth on an historic day at the China Open on Thursday.

item.title: China's youngest comrades
item.description: Allan Yang would be a success story in any country.

item.title: 'Mobsters' detained after clashes
item.description: Clashes in the unsettled western Chinese region of Xinjiang killed 21 people, including police officers and local officials, authorities said Wednesday.
